Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Studying advanced treatment methods for removal of pharmaceuticals from sewage effluent
Award.AbstractNarration:
The abundance of pharmaceuticals found in natural water sources has increased as their applications and production has increased. In the environment, pharmaceuticals have the potential to be toxic, increase microbial resistance, and yield other unforeseen environmental adverse effects. Effluents of municipal sewage treatment plants represent a major pollution source of pharmaceuticals in the environment. Therefore, it is of utmost importance to study different advanced treatment methods to further remove pharmaceuticals in sewage effluent. In collaboration with Dr. Zhimin Qiang, an expert in wastewater research at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, this study will determine the most applicable method to remove typical pharmaceuticals from sewage effluent by advanced treatment processes.

The toxicity, microbial resistance, and unforeseen adverse effects in the environment, induced by pharmaceuticals, necessitate a comprehensive study of abatement, degradation pathways, and toxicity changes of each target pollutant during advanced oxidation processes (AOPs). The selected AOPs include three O3-based and UV-based (e.g. O3/H2O2, UV/O3, and UV/H2O2) technologies, which have great potentials to effectively remove pharmaceuticals from sewage effluent. Six frequently detected pharmaceuticals in sewage effluent, including sulfadiazine (SDZ), sulfamethoxazole (SMX), trimethoprim (TMP), metoprolol (MET), roxithromycin (ROX), and caffeine (CAF), will be selected for this study. The abatement of these pharmaceuticals by the AOPs will be studied, along with their degradation byproducts identified by liquid chromatography time-of-flight mass spectrometry (LC/Q-TOF-MS) to propose degradation pathways. In addition, this project will evaluate the pollutant removal efficiency, energy consumption, and operation factors of the different AOPs, to determine the most applicable method. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To reduce environmental impact wastewater treatment plants are geared to not only remove nutrients, natural organic matter (NOM) and pathogens, but elimination or reduction of pharmaceuticals as well. As pharmaceutical use increases due to widespread usage in human and veterinary practices, concerns such as promotion of microbial resistance and environmental toxicity arise with increased multi-reuse of wastewater effluent. Many techniques are available for pollutant removal: adsorption, filtration, chemical treatment, oxidation, etc. The advantages and disadvantages must be considered for each technique: recyclability and facility down time, as well as the costs associated with operation, replacement, and disposal. The overall goal of this research was to improve water quality by designing an implementable technique to identify and quantify pharmaceuticals and their degradates, along with technology capable of incorporation into current wastewater treatment to target these pharmaceuticals.

 

This study utilized an established liquid chromatography – mass spectrometry (LC-MS) method to study dominant pharmaceuticals in municipal wastewater: sulfadiazine (SDZ), norfloxacin (NOR), trimethoprim (TMP), metoprolol (MET), roxithromycin (ROX), and caffeine (CAF). Abatement of the selected pharmaceuticals by UV-based and O3-based advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), i.e. UV/H2O2, O3/H2O2, and UV/O3, were conducted in ultrapure water and secondary wastewater effluent. The impacts of pH, NOM, and exposure time were also explored. The toxicity of each pharmaceutical pre- and post-AOP treatment were determined. Selected pharmaceuticals were studied via LC-MS and LC coupled to (quadrupole) time-of-flight mass spectrometry (LC/Q-TOF-MS) to determine potential degradates in wastewater, and to propose novel degradation pathways.

 

Degradation and degradation kinetic rate constants of these six pharmaceuticals were found to be dependent upon the matrix and pH. To determine the enhanced degradation induced by the AOPs, each pharmaceutical (100 µg/L) was first studied individually within each matrix under a UV lamp (4.55 mW/cm2). Samples were obtained at 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 10, and 15 minutes to determine degradation kinetics and rate constants for each pharmaceutical. In all matrices studied, UV degradation yielded 80% or higher removal efficiency for SDZ, and over 90% for NOR. However, ROX, MET, TMP, and CAF removal efficiencies were 65% or less in ultrapure water, and even lower (<45%) in buffered and waste waters. The degradation kinetics of NOR were drastically different between matrices, with the fastest kinetics in pH 7.5 buffered ultrapure water (0.725 min-1). NOR degradation kinetics in wastewater (0.185 min-1) were only slightly less than in ultrapure water, while SDZ degradation kinetics were found to be highest within wastewater (0.301 min-1). The other pharmaceuticals studied rate constants were all ≤0.065 min-1.

 

The selected pharmaceuticals for the elucidation of the abatement pathways by LC/Q-TOF-MS were chosen based on not being previously studied and their susceptibility to degradation by the treatment process. Therefore, TMP, NOR, and ROX were the potential pharmaceuticals chosen for investigation of their degradation pathways, contingent upon their susceptibility to degradation. Due to the low efficiency of UV degradation of TMP and ROX, only the abatement of NOR was pursued. The degradation pathway of NOR was studied in ultrapure water by sampling at 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 10, and 15 minutes after 1 mg/L NOR was added to the reactor. The toxicity of each sample was also examined to determine the potential risk of the byproducts.
